body: Why have the 2 last arguments if they are always the same?
I agree with you but this is a bigger change and should be a done in a separate PR because this one is intended to be a fix, not a replacement

What do you mean?
IIRC the blockchain size and chainstate size are two different things
Huh? Bigger? Please unresolved this.
Instead of arguments, you have access to m_blockchain_size and the other.

Are you sure?
IIRC it was only available in the contructor but I could be wrong, thats why I used this method
Both are members of `Intro`: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/7b701fef58f627956d597817a1f9422edd890cdc/src/qt/intro.h#L70-L71
Done, don't know why it didn't worked last time
Naming: s/isPruning/is_pruned/

This does not work if "-prune" is set:

```bash
src/qt/bitcoin-qt -prune=3000
```

![Screenshot from 2019-10-05 11-15-01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32963518/66252279-4b70b680-e762-11e9-80a5-fb9568535f5f.png)

Could get rid of the magic number `2`?
See:
- https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qt.html#CheckState-enum
- https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qabstractbutton.html#checked-prop
Sure, I will work on your suggested changes now
d35cfde6429dafe576f7490dd3fd880e70994fde
ea8ef9cde7b28fda72aa2313c92e6396e700e357
@hebasto Done

[Developer Notes - C++ data structures](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/developer-notes.md#c-data-structures):

> Initialize all non-static class members where they are defined.

[Developer Notes - Coding Style (C++)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/developer-notes.md#coding-style-c):

> - Variable (including function arguments) and namespace names are all lowercase and may use `_` to separate words (snake_case).
>   - Class member variables have a `m_` prefix.

Also a negated name is confusing. Could it be positive?
`ui->prune->isChecked()` is accessible here. `bool is_pruned` parameter seems redundant.
Yes, do this now
Oh yeah, it is just a remaining of the first version of this patch
You don't have to add this, just use `ui->prune->isChecked()`?
@promag I do, it is there to check if it touched by the user. If the user has used the checkbox once, this bool will go to false
Squashing done

Approach ACK 727f86f3a75051daaeb81cb3984574c06eb62449, tested on Linux Mint 19.2.

Nit: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17035#discussion_r331801244

Commit 727f86f3a75051daaeb81cb3984574c06eb62449 message "_... It also removes a useless boolean added before_" is a hint ;) Why to introduce a variable in a commit to remove it in the next one?

It does not work if disk space is insufficient _and_ `-prune=0` or  `-noprune` is passed as an command-line option (it could be leave for the following PRs, IMO).

EDIT: The "qt: Update the required space message when the prune box is checked" commit (727f86f3a75051daaeb81cb3984574c06eb62449) should deal with both `ui->prune->setChecked()` _and_ `pruneTarget`. The latter is ignored now ;)
Done

As I wrote:

> ... should deal with both `ui->prune->setChecked()` _and_ `pruneTarget`. The latter is ignored now ;)

More details are in the screenshot:
![Screenshot from 2019-10-07 20-02-26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32963518/66332637-da85f600-e93d-11e9-8790-57670671f7f9.png)

If `pruneTarget` is set to 2 GB, amount 3 GB of stored data is obviously incorrect.
@hebasto Sure, what is with the chainstate?

Tested a bit, something seems incorrect. If I start with `-prune=2000` I'll get a text "Approx 7GB" while when I start without `-prune`, I'll get 4GB as size warning.

I know this is not the place to discuss that, but why have we chosen 2GB as prune target instead of the minimum of 550MB?

> If I start with -prune=2000 I'll get a text "Approx 7GB" while when I start without -prune, I'll get 4GB as size warning.

I confirm this behavior, setting `-prune` on command line and setting in the UI should give the same approximation?

@promag @jonasschnelli 
I might xe wrong but this is a feature and not a bug. It is because the chainstate size is also being incremented to the required amount of storage. When you prune with 550MB your bitcoin folder will still be around 4-5GB huge and not 550MB

See Line 361:
```
requiredSpace += m_chain_state_size;
```
Push

Tested this PR on top of the current master (dcc640811c8c1a0678a3c3726cb7df14f0a60250).

---

```
src/qt/bitcoin-qt -chain=test -prune=2000
```
![Screenshot from 2019-10-15 10-56-44](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32963518/66811869-84ffa980-ef3a-11e9-942d-c4394285a0de.png)

That is correct, as 5 GB is a sum of pruned blockchain size (2 GB) and chainstate size (3 GB).

---

```
src/qt/bitcoin-qt -chain=test
```
![Screenshot from 2019-10-15 11-00-36](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32963518/66812158-0ce5b380-ef3b-11e9-9632-4f750144b589.png)

That is _wrong_, as 2 GB is the default pruned blockchain size, and chainstate size is skipped.

@promag

> I confirm this behavior, setting `-prune` on command line and setting in the UI should give the same approximation?

Yes, they should.
Ok, will work on specific chain selection now
@hebasto Fixed, squashed and ready for merge
